The '''court-martial of Terry Lakin''' took place over December 14–16, 2010. Doctor Terry Lakin, a [[lieutenant colonel (United States)|lieutenant colonel]] in the [[United States Army]], announced that he would refuse deployment, and subsequently refused to deploy to [[Afghanistan]] because of his [[Barack Obama citizenship conspiracy theories|concerns over President Obama's constitutional eligibility to be president]]. It was Lakin's hope that he could request a copy of Obama's [[birth certificate]] as part of a court-martial, a goal that had eluded previous military defendants. Lakin had the support of three retired American generals, two of whom were working for [[Fox News Channel]] at the time. Before Lakin went to [[court-martial]], it was found by the judge that President Obama's eligibility (and hence his birth certificate) had no bearing on the case. Lakin pleaded guilty to two charges while pleading not-guilty to one other. Despite recanting his original concerns and asking the jury for leniency, Lakin was found guilty of all charges and sentenced to dismissal from the Army and a prison term of six months. Lakin was released from the [[United States Disciplinary Barracks]] after serving five of his six months. He was later denied a [[medical license]] in [[Kansas]] as a result of his dereliction of duty. ==Background== {{Infobox person | name = Terrence Lee Lakin | honorific_suffix = D.O., M.P.H. | image = OEF Mar10 2005 Division Flight surgeons honored in Afghanistan01 (Lakin crop).jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Lakin in Afghanistan (2005) | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = Terry Lakin | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = Soldier

orders to report to [[Fort Campbell]], [[Kentucky]] on April 12, 2010,{{cite news | title = Army birther under investigation | first = Jen | last = Dimascio | url = http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0410/35823.html#ixzz0lGNbSEnt | newspaper = [[Politico (newspaper)|Politico]] | publisher = [[Allbritton Communications Company]] | location = [[Arlington County, [[military deployment|deployment]] to [[Afghanistan]].{{cite news | title = Army to court martial 'birther' officer | first = Jim | last = Miklaszewski | authorlink = Jim Miklaszewski | author2 = Mark Murray | url = http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2010/04/13/4429371-army-to-court-martial-birther-officer | publisher = [[NBC News]] | location = [[GE Building]], [[New York City]], US | date = 2010-04-13 | accessdate = 2011-01-02 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5vRlovhKJ | dead-url = yes | archivedate = 2011-01-02 }}{{cite video | people = Lakin, Terry | date = 2010-03-30 | title = American Patriot Foundation: FTC Terry Lakin Defense Fund | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ea9JVnck_-E | publisher = [[YouTube]] | location = [[San Bruno, California]], US | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5vRm5nX35 | dead-url = no | archivedate = 2011-01-02 | accessdate = 2011-01-02 }} On March 30, 2010, American Patriot Foundation, Inc. (APF) posted a video to [[YouTube]] of Lakin explaining his intent to disobey what he believed to be "illegal orders". Lakin explained that "all orders have their origin with the [[Commander-in-chief#United States|Commander-in-Chief]]", and he claimed that [[Barack Obama|President Obama]] had not satisfactorily proven his [[Article Two of the United States Constitution#Clause 5: Qualifications for office|constitutional eligibility]] for his station, so those orders could not be followed. President Obama had already released an image of his record of birth that showed he was born in Hawaii.{{cite news | last1 = Hollyfield | first1 = Amy | date = 2008-06-27 | title = Obama's birth certificate: Final chapter | url = http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/article/2008/jun/27/obamas-birth-certificate-part-ii/ | dead-url = no | publisher = [[Politico]] | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150926215748/http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/article/2008/jun/27/obamas-birth-certificate-part-ii/ | archive-date = 2015-09-26 | access-date = 2015-12-09 }} Lakin invited his court-martial to cause the president's legitimacy to be scrutinized, but also because he wanted the president to produce his original 1961 [[birth certificate]] to prove his "birth on American soil" and [[natural born citizen of the United States|natural born]]-status. Margaret Hemenway, speaking for the APF to [[Salon (website)|''Salon'']], repeatedly claimed that President Obama hadn't even released the same birth certificate Lakin had to give the military. The APF also raised funds to assist in Lakin's defense. Prior to April 12, Army officials stated they were aware of Lakin's intent to "violate articles 87 and 92 of [the] [[Uniform Code of Military Justice]]", but until he did so they had nothing further upon which to comment.{{cite magazine | last1 = Koppelman | first1 = Alex | date = 2010-04-05 | title = New soldier joins Birthers' anti-Obama crusade | journal = [[Salon (magazine)|Salon]] | publisher = Salon Media Group | accessdate = 2011-01-02 | url = http://www.salon.com/news/politics/war_room/2010/04/05/birther_soldier_terrence_lakin | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5vRpMK2xA | dead-url = no | archivedate = 2011-01-02 | quote = Army lieutenant colonel says he'll refuse to obey any orders because of his concerns about president's eligibility }} Instead of complying with his deployment orders, Lakin reported to [[the Pentagon]]. After being [[Miranda warning|Mirandized]] and informed by his [[commanding officer]]—[[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] [[Gordon Ray Roberts]]—that he would face court-martial, Lakin's Pentagon [[access badge]] and governmental [[laptop]] were confiscated. Pending his court-martial, Lakin was assigned to duty at [[Walter Reed Army Medical Center]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]. ===Analysis=== [[Salon (website)|''Salon'']] contributor Alex Koppelman noted that LTC Lakin was not the first [[United States Armed Forces|US military]] member to "become a [[birther]] cause celebre", indicating the cases of Major Stefan F. Cook ([[Orly Taitz#Cook v. Good|''Cook v. Good'']]) and Captain Connie Rhodes ([[Orly Taitz#Rhodes v. MacDonald|''Rhodes v. MacDonald'']]). Koppelman explained that neither of these lawsuits succeeded in a ruling on Obama's eligibility to be president. In contrast, since a court case (in this case, a court-martial) was the likely conclusion to Lakin's actions, his attorneys hoped that he could seek President Obama's original birth certificate for use in his defense. ===Commentary by others=== Prior to Lakin officially violating his order to deploy, former Republican [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Bob Smith (American politician)|Bob Smith]], who founded the American Patriot Foundation, said: "...my personal belief is that when an officer has a constitutional question I don't have a problem with that being answered, that's his legal right to have that answered, but I'm not involved in it." Three retired United States generals expressed support for Lakin. The first was retired Army [[Major general (United States)|Major General]] [[Paul E. Vallely]], a senior [[military analyst]] for [[Fox News Channel|Fox News]]. In an interview, Vallely stated "I think many in the military – and many out of the military – question the natural-birth status of Barack Obama."{{cite news | title = Lakin receives support from retired Army General | first = Jack | last = Minor | url = http://www.greeleygazette.com/press/?p=2322 | newspaper = [[Greeley Gazette]] | publisher = Zera Communications | location = [[Greeley, Colorado]], US | issn = | date = 2010-04-29 | accessdate = 2011-01-06 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5vY0FYP0X | dead-url = yes | archivedate = 2011-01-06 }} Following Vallely's announcement, retired Army Major General Jerry Curry{{cite news | title = Second General backs Lakin, says President should produce birth certificate | first = Jack | last = Minor | url = http://www.greeleygazette.com/press/?p=4755 | newspaper = [[Greeley Gazette]] | publisher = Zera Communications | location = [[Greeley, Colorado]], US | issn = | date = 2010-08-09 | accessdate = 2011-01-06 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5vY0PugoX | dead-url = no | archivedate = 2011-01-06 }} and retired [[United States Air Force|Air Force]] [[Lieutenant general (United States)|Lieutenant General]] (and Fox News analyst) [[Thomas McInerney]]{{cite news | title = Fox News Military Analyst Comes Out As Birther | first = Jason | last = Linkins | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/09/01/fox-news-military-analyst_n_702516.html | newspaper = [[The Huffington Post]] | location = [[New York City]], US | date = 2010-09-01 | accessdate = 2011-01-06 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5vY0mjbtC | dead-url = no | archivedate = 2011-01-06 }} also expressed public support for Lakin. ==Trial== In September 2010, Lakin's military judge, Colonel Denise Lind, ruled that whether President Obama is constitutionally qualified for office had no legal bearing on Lakin's case. As such, Lakin could not make any demands for the president's birth certificate as part of his trial.{{cite news | date = 2010-12-14 | title = Army Birther Terrence Lakin Pleads Guilty After Disobeying Orders | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/14/army-birther-terrence-lakin_n_796351.html | newspaper = [[The Huffington Post]] | location = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | publisher = [[AOL]] | publication-date = 2010-12-14 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101218042009/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/14/army-birther-terrence-lakin_n_796351.html? | dead-url = no | archivedate = 2010-12-18 | accessdate = 2014-05-06 }} On December 14, 2010, the first day of Lakin's court-martial at [[Fort George G. Meade]], jurors were asked about their awareness of the "birther movement". Lakin pleaded guilty to violating article 92 of the [[Uniform Code of Military Justice]] (UCMJ) (failing to meet with a superior officer and failing to report to duty at [[Fort Campbell]]), and pleaded not guilty to violating article 87 of the UCMJ (missing a flight on which he was required); the court-martial continued on the second charge.{{cite news | title = Army birther pleads guilty to 1 of 2 charges | url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/40661450/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/ | agency = [[Associated Press]] | publisher = [[MSNBC]] | location = [[GE Building]], [[New York City]], US | date = 2010-12-14 | accessdate = 2011-01-01 | quote = The physician disobeyed orders to deploy to Afghanistan because he questions President Barack Obama's citizenship | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5vQbQvd5p | dead-url = yes | archivedate = 2011-01-01 }}{{cite news | last1 = Hemmerly-Brown | first1 = Alexandra | date = 2010-12-15 | title = Army doctor pleads guilty to three specifications in court-martial | url = http://www.army.mil/article/49466/ | publisher = [[United States Army]] | publication-date = 2010-12-15 | agency = Army News Service | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140506222243/http://www.army.mil/article/49466/ | dead-url = no | archivedate = 2014-05-06 | accessdate = 2014-05-06 }} [[File:Lakin court-martial sketch (crop).jpg|thumb|[[Courtroom sketch]] of Lakin (left) and jurors (right) made 15 December]] Facing up to 3.5 years in military prison and dismissal from the Army, on December 15 Lakin changed tack and stated that he was wrong to question the president's qualifications through his military service. He requested that the jury allow him to continue his career in the military ("I don't want it to end this way, I want to continue to serve"), and that he would now undertake his deployment if he could, even with his concerns about the president unaddressed. The defense brought witnesses before the court to testify on Lakin's behalf, describing the accused as a "compassionate physician" who always volunteered to help when needed. The prosecution introduced the officer that was deployed in Lakin's stead, who testified alongside his wife about how the last-minute deployment affected their lives.{{cite news | date = 2010-12-15 | title = 'Army Birther' Terrence Larkin Changes Course, Says Will Deploy | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/15/terrence-lakin-army-birther_n_797337.html | newspaper = [[The Huffington Post]] | location = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | publisher = [[AOL]] | publication-date = 2010-12-15 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101218041115/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/15/terrence-lakin-army-birther_n_797337.html | dead-url = no | archivedate = 2010-12-18 | accessdate = 2014-05-06 }} Lakin was found guilty of all charges on December 16. After five hours of deliberation, the jury sentenced him to six months in a military prison and dismissal from the Army, the sentence was approved by [[Major general|Major General]] Karl Horst. Lakin would begin his sentence immediately, though an automatic appeal would go before the [[United States Army Court of Criminal Appeals]].{{cite news | date = 2010-12-16 | title = Terrence Lakin Sentence: 'Army Birther' Gets 6 Months In Military Prison | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/16/terrence-lakin-sentence_n_797906.html | newspaper = [[The Huffington Post]] | location = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | publisher = [[AOL]] | publication-date = 2010-12-16 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101218183014/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/16/terrence-lakin-sentence_n_797906.html | dead-url = no | archivedate = 2010-12-18 | accessdate = 2014-05-06 }}{{cite news | last1 = Hemmerly-Brown | first1 = Alexandra | date = 2010-12-17 | title = Lakin discharged, sentenced to six months | url = http://www.army.mil/article/49601/ | publisher = [[United States Army]] | publication-date = 2010-12-17 | agency = Army News Service | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140506215028/http://www.army.mil/article/49601/ | dead-url = no | archivedate = 2014-05-06 | accessdate = 2014-05-06 }} ==Confinement and beyond== Lakin served five months in the [[United States Disciplinary Barracks]] at [[Fort Leavenworth]], being released a month early on May 13, 2011.{{cite news | last1 = Jordan | first1 = Bryant | date = 2011-05-18 | title = Ex-Army 'Birther' Doctor Released From Leavenworth | url = http://www.military.com/news/article/ex-army-birther-doctor-released-from-leavenworth.html | publisher = [[Military.com]] | publication-date = 2011-05-18 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110621011002/http://www.military.com/news/article/ex-army-birther-doctor-released-from-leavenworth.html? | dead-url = yes | archivedate = 2011-06-21 }} On July 28, 2011, the United States Army Court of Criminal Appeals granted Lakin's request to withdraw his case from appellate review.{{cite web|url=http://www.caaflog.com/wp-content/uploads/Lakin-order.pdf|title=United States v. Terrence L. Lakin|accessdate=August 2, 2011|date=July 28, 2011|format=PDF}} Speaking on the subject of his outstanding appeals in June 2011, Lakin foresaw no complications in continuing to practice medicine.{{cite news | last1 = Jordan | first1 = Bryant | date = 2011-06-28 | title = Birther Doc Wants Some Benefits | url = http://www.military.com/news/article/birther-doc-wants-some-benefits.html | publisher = [[Military.com]] | publication-date = 2011-06-28 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110629204802/http://www.military.com/news/article/birther-doc-wants-some-benefits.html | dead-url = yes | archivedate = 2011-06-29 }} On 21 October 2011, the [[Kansas State Board of Healing Arts]] denied Lakin a [[medical license|license]] to practice medicine in Kansas saying he "potentially jeopardized the health, safety and welfare of the military troops for which applicant was employed to provide medical care." Lakin later co-authored a book on his experiences, ''Officer's Oath: Why My Vow to Defend the Constitution Demanded that I Sacrifice My Career''.{{cite book | url = http://www.amazon.com/OFFICER-OATH-Constitution-demanded-sacrifice/dp/0578086646 | title = OFFICER'S OATH: Why my vow to defend the Constitution demanded that I sacrifice my career | last1 = Lakin | first1 = Terry | last2 = Cashill | first2 = Jack | last3 = Mercaldo | first3 = David | website = [[Amazon.com]] | isbn = 978-0578086644 | accessdate = 2014-05-06 }} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lakin, Terry}} [[Category:21st-century American criminals]] [[Category:Conspiracy theories regarding Barack Obama]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of the United States military]]
